values.title: crash with Ogre assertion

content.raw:
Following the tutorial at:

[http://gazebosim.org/wiki/Tutorials/1.2/beginner/build_world](http://gazebosim.org/wiki/Tutorials/1.2/beginner/build_world)

I created a world with a cube, sphere, cylinder, firehose, and Turtlebot.  I dropped the firehose on the sphere and it rolled away.  I saved the world after this.  I continued to use the simulator dropping the firehose and the turtlebot on the other objects, as well as adjusting the ambient lighting in the scene.  At some later point, the simulator crashed with the following error.

~~~
willow@toshiba:~/build_world_tutorial$ Gazebo multi-robot simulator, version 1.2
Copyright (C) 2011 Nate Koenig, John Hsu, and contributors.
Released under the Apache 2 License.
http://gazebosim.org

Gazebo multi-robot simulator, version 1.2
Copyright (C) 2011 Nate Koenig, John Hsu, and contributors.
Released under the Apache 2 License.
http://gazebosim.org

Msg Waiting for master
Msg Connected to gazebo master @ http://localhost:11345
Msg Waiting for master
Msg Connected to gazebo master @ http://localhost:11345
gazebo: /tmp/buildd/ros-fuerte-visualization-common-1.8.4/debian/ros-fuerte-visualization-common/opt/ros/fuerte/stacks/visualization_common/ogre/build/ogre_src_v1-7-3/OgreMain/src/OgreNode.cpp:413: virtual void Ogre::Node::setPosition(const Ogre::Vector3&): Assertion `!pos.isNaN() && "Invalid vector supplied as parameter"' failed.

[1]+  Done                    gazebo my_world.sdf
willow@toshiba:~/build_world_tutorial$ gazebo my_world.sdf &
~~~

values.title: Hokuyo laser sensor in DRC Sim should conform to REP 117

content.raw: Most importantly, it suggests  that distance values that don't represent a valid measurement be "represented by -Inf, NaN, and +Inf respectively and as defined within floating point standards." This has been reflected in the ROS hardware drivers for the Hokuya and the SICK.
content.html: Most importantly, it suggests that distance values that don't represent a valid measurement be "represented by -Inf, NaN, and +Inf respectively and as defined within floating point standards." This has been reflected in the ROS hardware drivers for the Hokuya and the SICK.

values.title: Tutorial Copy and Paste Blocks should be a different color

content.raw:
When the copy and paste block has something that needs user to fill in,

~~~
cp /home/[your username]/.gazebo/...  foo/bar
~~~

highlight the part that needs to be filled in.

One way is to spell it out:
~~~
Replace [your username] with your username before copying and pasting
cp /home/[your username]/.gazebo/...  foo/bar
~~~
content.html:
When the copy and paste block has something that needs user to fill in,

cp /home/[your username]/.gazebo/...  foo/bar

highlight the part that needs to be filled in.

One way is to spell it out:

Replace [your username] with your username before copying and pasting
cp /home/[your username]/.gazebo/...  foo/bar

values.title: model delete:  left over plugin event from deleted model causes segfault on gzserver

content.raw:
Model tear down is incomplete, to reproduce, insert pioneer2dx model, delete pioneer2dx model, insert anything else.  gzserver will fail trying to call event left over by the pioneer2dx model when inserting the second model with following backtrace:

~~~

values.title: Using Model Joint Control pauses GUI UserCamera view updates

content.raw: When applying force to a model using the joint control gui widget, the main GUI window stops updating.  Clicking on the GUI window, resumes UserCamera update, the model state "warps" forward in time to the current state.
content.html: When applying force to a model using the joint control gui widget, the main GUI window stops updating. Clicking on the GUI window, resumes UserCamera update, the model state "warps" forward in time to the current state.

values.title: plugin destructors not called on shutdown

content.raw: When gazebo shuts down (ctrl-c, or gui quit), system plugin destructors are not called.
content.html: When gazebo shuts down (ctrl-c, or gui quit), system plugin destructors are not called.

values.title: automatically import model references from model database

content.raw:
If user creates a model that depends on another model (or its mesh) in the model database.  Given a correct `GAZEBO_MODEL_DATABASE_URI`, the import of the dependent model and meshes should happen automatically when user tries to spawn the custom model.

In the tutorial [Attach Mesh Tutorial](http://gazebosim.org/wiki/Tutorials/1.2/build_robot/attach_meshes), spawning the user created model should pull in the pioneer2dx model automatically.
content.html:
If user creates a model that depends on another model (or its mesh) in the model database. Given a correct GAZEBO_MODEL_DATABASE_URI, the import of the dependent model and meshes should happen automatically when user tries to spawn the custom model.

In the tutorial Attach Mesh Tutorial, spawning the user created model should pull in the pioneer2dx model automatically.

values.title: In tutorials, highlight where it says, “You’ll get an error but disregard it”

content.raw: It's easy to miss that line
content.html: It's easy to miss that line

values.title: Warn users when they try to run more than one Gazebo

content.raw: Some tutorials say “Start Gazebo”, but it doesn’t say that you should shut down the one already running first. Perhaps print to console that you have another instance of Gazebo up and that you should shut it down
content.html: Some tutorials say “Start Gazebo”, but it doesn’t say that you should shut down the one already running first. Perhaps print to console that you have another instance of Gazebo up and that you should shut it down

values.title: On Gazebo site, advertise the SDF documentation

content.raw: Perhaps add it to the home page by the Wiki, API and User Guide mentions. Some folks didn't know it was available
content.html: Perhaps add it to the home page by the Wiki, API and User Guide mentions. Some folks didn't know it was available

values.title: crossed OGRE configuration possible

content.raw:
In the following situation:

* libogre-1.7.4 is installed
* gazebo is configured to use ogre from ros-fuerte-visualization-common

Gazebo will build against the ROS ogre correctly, but will generate an incorrect `setup.sh` with a line like this:

        export OGRE_RESOURCE_PATH=/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/OGRE-1.7.3:/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/OGRE:

It's because Gazebo is finding ogre's library path by searching certain locations in the filesystem, but finding ogre's build flags via pkg-config.  The two results are then mixed into the bad line.

An easy workaround is to not have libogre-1.7.4 installed.
content.html:
In the following situation:

  • libogre-1.7.4 is installed
  • gazebo is configured to use ogre from ros-fuerte-visualization-common

Gazebo will build against the ROS ogre correctly, but will generate an incorrect setup.sh with a line like this:

    export OGRE_RESOURCE_PATH=/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/OGRE-1.7.3:/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/OGRE:

It's because Gazebo is finding ogre's library path by searching certain locations in the filesystem, but finding ogre's build flags via pkg-config. The two results are then mixed into the bad line.

An easy workaround is to not have libogre-1.7.4 installed.

values.title: contact sensor state

content.raw:
Contact sensor states do not seem to be initialized and updated correctly. 

Problems:

i) a contact sensor is only initialized upon the first contact with an object, until then gazebo spams the console with "Error [ContactSensor.cc:237] Contact Sensor[/r2/right_leg_foot_force0_contact_sensor] has no collision[r2c_body::/r2/right_leg_foot_force0::/r2/right_leg_foot_force0_geom]" errors

ii) after losing contact with an object the contact sensor seems to keep the collision stored (i.e. collision object names and contact position(s)) and publishes it as contact with zero force instead of publishing an empty list (which would be the expected behaviour I guess)
content.html:
Contact sensor states do not seem to be initialized and updated correctly.

Problems:

i) a contact sensor is only initialized upon the first contact with an object, until then gazebo spams the console with "Error [ContactSensor.cc:237] Contact Sensor[/r2/right_leg_foot_force0_contact_sensor] has no collision[r2c_body::/r2/right_leg_foot_force0::/r2/right_leg_foot_force0_geom]" errors

ii) after losing contact with an object the contact sensor seems to keep the collision stored (i.e. collision object names and contact position(s)) and publishes it as contact with zero force instead of publishing an empty list (which would be the expected behaviour I guess)

I've upgraded to gazebo-1.2.5, and I'm still seeing similar issues.  The clouds and background render, but there's no ground plane.  And when I insert models, none of them seem to have textures.  I've attached a screenshot of empty.world to give you an idea.

I'm running Fedora 17 x86_64.  The package versions on my system are:

gazebo-1.2.5-1.fc17.x86_64

libccd-1.4-1.fc17.x86_64

values.title: Enable sharing of resources (like textures) between models

content.raw: As briefly talked about at the DRC simulator tutorial session, it can make sense to make shared resources (like textures) available to multiple models. At the moment, this does not seem to be possible. A example where this would be useful is provided in [pull request #1 for gazebo_models](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/pull-request/1/added-multiple-nist-astm-standard-test/diff). Here, multiple NIST standard test arena elements all use the same texture. Currently, every model has to provide it's own copy of that texture, which clearly isn't space-efficient.

At the moment, this does not seem to be possible. A example where this would be useful is provided in pull request #1 for gazebo_models. Here, multiple NIST standard test arena elements all use the same texture. Currently, every model has to provide it's own copy of that texture, which clearly isn't space-efficient.

values.title: Create video recording widget for GUI

content.raw:
Users should have access to an easy video-making tool in the GUI. 

Possible features/characteristics:
	- should record the robot and the state of the controllers (to make rewinding possible)
	- users can drag a marker back and forth to scan through the simulation (rewindable)
	- users can change params like speed and replay the simulation faster/slower
        - let users zoom in/out on the data
        - "Track & Dolly" views: toggle that lets you set the camera so it tracks the robot from a stationary position, or moves alongside the robot like a dolly
        - users can add keyframes to a simulation recording so that it’s possible to jump from one important spot to another in the recording
        - option to Save State (screenshot) or Save Data (takes video and records controllers as well) 
	- video can be reloaded and played
	- offer different camera angles for video-making so the robot doesn’t zoom off-screen
content.html:
Users should have access to an easy video-making tool in the GUI.

Possible features/characteristics: - should record the robot and the state of the controllers (to make rewinding possible) - users can drag a marker back and forth to scan through the simulation (rewindable) - users can change params like speed and replay the simulation faster/slower - let users zoom in/out on the data - "Track & Dolly" views: toggle that lets you set the camera so it tracks the robot from a stationary position, or moves alongside the robot like a dolly - users can add keyframes to a simulation recording so that it’s possible to jump from one important spot to another in the recording - option to Save State (screenshot) or Save Data (takes video and records controllers as well) - video can be reloaded and played - offer different camera angles for video-making so the robot doesn’t zoom off-screen

values.title: Model manifest files in ROS_PACKAGE_PATH confuse rqt_gui plugin loader

content.raw: If I use the setup.sh script as described in the [drcsim install instructions](http://gazebosim.org/wiki/InstallDRC), the model directories are added to the ROS_PACKAGE_PATH. This causes errors in rqt_gui's plugin loader, as it apparently reads the manifest and does not find the expected (ROS) entries there (see attached file). It can perhaps be argued if this should be ticketed against gazebo or rqt_gui (asked Dirk, he says non-ROS manifest files have no business being in the ROS_PACKAGE_PATH).
content.html: If I use the setup.sh script as described in the drcsim install instructions, the model directories are added to the ROS_PACKAGE_PATH. This causes errors in rqt_gui's plugin loader, as it apparently reads the manifest and does not find the expected (ROS) entries there (see attached file). It can perhaps be argued if this should be ticketed against gazebo or rqt_gui (asked Dirk, he says non-ROS manifest files have no business being in the ROS_PACKAGE_PATH).

values.title: Object Placement

content.raw:
It might be nice to have objects placed on top of existing surface instead of height 0. For example when placing objects on uneven/elevated terrain the object should follow the terrain instead of the ground plane. Maybe it should also automatically go on top of other objects at the same location (e.g. when there's a table the object would automatically be placed on top of the table). 
You could allow the user to switch between this mode and the existing mode where models are placed on the ground plane (at height 0).

What I'm talking about is actually known as "Follow Terrain" and "Follow Terrain and Objects" modes in some game engine editors (e.g. Cry Engine 3 Editor: http://freesdk.crydev.net/display/SDKDOC2/Placing+and+Modifying+Objects).

values.title: Changing floating point numbers in property tree

content.raw: When changing floating point numbers in the property tree (e.g. when trying to change the pose of an object or step size of the simulator) you can't simply add digits to the right of the decimal point because the input seems to be restricted to six decimal places. You first need to "make space" by removing trailing zeros or other digits. This restriction does not prevent you from adding numbers to the left of the decimal point though or when modifying integer numbers.

values.title: nanosleep on systems with large clock timer resolution leads to slow simulation

content.raw:
On systems with boot flags `acpi=off`, clock resolution could be large (>=4ms in some instances).  This leads to simulation rates at 1/4 of real-time or slower if any non-zero physics `<update_rate>` is specified.  Setting physics `<update_rate>` to 0 leads to unthrottled simulation.

A pull request #72 has been created to check and make sure clock resolution is smaller than requested sleep time, otherwise skip sleep and defaults back to busy-loop behavior.
content.html:
On systems with boot flags acpi=off, clock resolution could be large (>=4ms in some instances). This leads to simulation rates at 1/4 of real-time or slower if any non-zero physics <update_rate> is specified. Setting physics <update_rate> to 0 leads to unthrottled simulation.

A pull request #72 has been created to check and make sure clock resolution is smaller than requested sleep time, otherwise skip sleep and defaults back to busy-loop behavior.

values.title: API Change and Camera::MoveToPosition actually does Camera::MoveToPose, consider tic-toc-ing to the correct behavior and add a MoveToPose function.

content.raw:
Both `Camera::MoveToPosition` and `UserCamera::MoveToPosition` took 3 doubles in 1.2.0, but takes a `math::Pose` in 1.2.5.

Consider adding a MoveToPose and making MoveToPosition actually do translation only motion animation or deprecate it.
content.html:
Both Camera::MoveToPosition and UserCamera::MoveToPosition took 3 doubles in 1.2.0, but takes a math::Pose in 1.2.5.

Consider adding a MoveToPose and making MoveToPosition actually do translation only motion animation or deprecate it.

values.title: Inserting a bad sdf model does not do anything, no console error/warnings.

content.raw:
Try inserting a model with bad SDF:

~~~
<model name="test">
  <link name="test1">
    <visual name="v1">
      <geometry>
        <box><size>1 1 1</size></box>
      </geometry_typo_bad>
    </visual>
  </link>
</model>
~~~

does not produce any warning/error messages.
content.html:
Try inserting a model with bad SDF:

<model name="test">
  <link name="test1">
    <visual name="v1">
      <geometry>
        <box><size>1 1 1</size></box>
      </geometry_typo_bad>
    </visual>
  </link>
</model>

does not produce any warning/error messages.
